section.title: Check BIND if DNSSEC-capable
section.para: First of all, all versions of BIND9 supports DNSSEC. The BIND software you are running may already support DNSSEC as shipped. Run the code named -V to see what flags it was built with. If it was built with OpenSSL (--with-openssl), then it supports DNSSEC. Below is an example screenshot of running named -V: $ /usr/sbin/named -V BIND 9.8.4-rpz2+rl005.12-P1 built with '--prefix=/usr' '--mandir=/usr/share/man' '--infodir=/usr/share/info' '--sysconfdir=/etc/bind' '--localstatedir=/var' '--enable-threads' '--enable-largefile' '--with-libtool' '--enable-shared' '--enable-static' '--with-openssl=/usr' '--with-gssapi=/usr' '--with-gnu-ld' '--with-geoip=/usr' '--enable-ipv6' 'CFLAGS=-fno-strict-aliasing -DDIG_SIGCHASE -O2' using OpenSSL version: OpenSSL 1.0.1e 11 Feb 2013 using libxml2 version: 2.8.0
If the BIND9 software you have does not support DNSSEC, it may be necessary to rebuild it from source. At the very minimum, you need to use the --with-openssl switch during configuration.

section.title: System Entropy
section.para: If you plan on deploying DNSSEC to your authoritative server, you will need to generate some cryptographic keys. The amount of time it takes to generate the keys depends on the source of randomness, or entropy, on your systems, and on some systems it may take several hours to generate keys.

There are software packages, such as haveged for Linux, that provides additional entropy for your system. Once installed, it will significantly reduce the time needed to generate keys from hours down to seconds.
